awd_titl_txt: Removing the Barriers to the Calculation of Activation Energies, Activation Volumes, and Mechanistic Insight for Chemical Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
Ward Thompson of the University of Kansas is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models, and Computational Methods program in the Division of Chemistry to develop methods for predicting the temperature dependence of dynamics in chemical systems.   Changing such external properties is a key way to control chemistry in a laboratory or industrial setting.  Thus, it is important to understand how these variables affect the timescales of the important motions involved in the chemistry. This knowledge also provides insight into the molecular-level motions that determine the timescale.  The methods developed in this project, for example, allow the direct calculation of the temperature dependence of any timescale (such as the time for a chemical reaction to take place) from simulations at a single temperature.  At the same time, they   give information about the molecular interactions that influence the temperature dependence.  Currently, no other method can provide such information.   In addition to the behavior with temperature, the effect of other properties such as pressure or system composition may be calculated.  While the approaches apply to any chemical system, the Thompson group is focusing on dynamics in liquids.  The award also supports an outreach program for elementary school students to increase their interest in and motivation for science.  It is designed to let the students see what scientists do and encourage them to view themselves as scientists through activities and interactions with graduate students and faculty. 

The methods developed fall into three categories:  1) Those enabling the calculation of activation energies for reactions and other dynamical processes from simulations at a single temperature. These approaches provide otherwise unattainable information: the contributions of different interactions to the activation energy. 2) Those evaluating changes in dynamical timescales with physical conditions other than temperature, such as pressure or chemical potential. This makes quantities like the activation volume available from simulations at a single pressure.  3) Approaches for calculating derivatives of rate constants and other dynamical timescales with respect to components of the underlying Hamiltonian, such as masses or potential parameters, to gain insight into mechanisms, force fields, and kinetic isotope effects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
How the dynamics of a reaction changes with temperature is one of the most fundamental measures of its behavior.  This is most commonly characterized by its activation energy, which is a key measure of the energy barrier that must be overcome for the reaction to occur.  The activation energy is obtained through measurement or simulation of the reaction rate constant at different temperatures. In this project, methods for obtaining the activation energy for simulations at a single temperature have been developed and applied.  One key advantage of these approaches is that the temperature dependence can be obtained even when varying the temperature is problematic, e.g., increasing temperature would lead to evaporation of the liquid under study.  A second advantage, exploited in this work, is that mechanistic information can be extracted that is not available any other way.  Specifically, the contribution to the activation energy from different motions or interactions present in the reactants can be determined; each contribution measures how helpful (or unhelpful) putting energy into that interaction is for passing over the reaction barrier.  A third advantage is that the methods developed in this project are applicable to determine the temperature dependence of any chemical process, not only reaction, including dynamical properties such as molecular diffusion, reorientation, viscosity, and spectroscopy as well as static properties, such as the liquid structure or the equilibrium between molecular conformations.

The methods developed in the project have been primarily applied to better understand the behavior of water and aqueous electrolytes. In one example, simulations at room temperature were used to predict the dynamics of water well into the supercooled regime (where water is cooled below its freezing point sufficiently quickly that it cannot form ice). This work showed that the behavior of supercooled water, which is difficult to probe experimentally, can be deduced from the behavior of water under ambient conditions.  In another example, the effect of ions on water diffusion, which is important in applications ranging from electrochemical cells to biological systems, was found to have a strong contribution from entropic effects.  Such insight can help understand the so-called Hofmeister effect, which describes how ions affect protein structure, solubility, and interactions. In a third case, simulations using the developed approaches corrected a long-standing interpretation of certain ultrafast spectroscopic experiments as a measurement of the timescale for water molecules to exchange hydrogen bond partners.  The work showed that hydrogen bond exchange is only a small, nearly negligible contribution to the experimental signal. This indicates that rethinking is required for how hydrogen bond exchanges, the most basic steps in rearrangements of water, can be directly probed.

Codes implementing the methods developed through this project have been made available to the scientific community.  In addition, seven graduate students were trained as part of this research, including four who completed their PhD during the grant period.  The PI and graduate students also participated in outreach activities including a 3D visualization demonstration of molecules during the annual Carnival of Chemistry at the University of Kansas.
